characters: THEN HE TURNS. WALKS TO CAMERA AND WE---
FACIAL EXPRESSIONS FROM ALL THE CAST.
AROUND THEM AND AS THE CAMERA MOVES BEHIND PETER WE..
AND HE WALKS INTO THE HALLWAY THROUGH THE FRONT DOOR,
GLORIA ARRIVED IN NEW YORK AND WAS ADMITTED TO ST.
AND AS THE TUBE LIGHTS FLICKER ON AND OFF WE--
AS HE CARRIES HER, LIPS LOCKED, TOWARDS THE BED

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ‘La Poo Boo Moo..' Eye-line pencil; cherry-red lipstick; ‘Saks of Fifth Avenue’ COMPACT MIRROR, intricately engraved with “Love Bogie ‘In A Lonely Place’ 1950”; Elnett hair laquer; Chanel perfume. A larger BROKEN HAND-MIRROR. A GOLDEN LOVE HEART PENDANT (opens with a sychronised tune). All Gloria’s ‘tools’ procured from a TATTY GREEN WASH-BAG, a trusted witness to her ‘process’ probably a thousand times or more. GLORIA (0.C.) (CONT’D) ‘Major Mickey's Malt Makes Me Merry.’ Costume: Peek at pale flesh and slim limbs as she climbs into a black, pleated wrap around dress with a plunging neckline; black stockings and princess slippers.. the dress hangs loose, too loose.. the belt tightened as far as it can go.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANANGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Five minutes Miss Grahame.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Thanks honey. Gloria’s tongue CLUCKS the roof of her mouth in approval, it’s one of her things.  INT. DUKE’S PLAYHOUSE THEATRE/STAGE - LATER WE CLASP EYES on Gloria for the first time being AMANDA WIGFIELD in the ‘Glass Menagerie’. Owning the stage. Acting her guts out goddamit.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA/GLORIA
dialogues.text: “That's why you act like this! I don't believe you go every night to the movies! Nobody goes to the movies night after night. Nobody in their right minds goes to the movies as often as you pretend to!” Gloria’s eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. DUKE’S PLAYHOUSE THEATRE — CONTINUOUS APPLAUSE from a small, enthusiastic AUDIENCE. Gloria takes her curtain call and theatrically welcomes her fellow ACTORS on stage. They hold hands and bow..

dialogues.speaker: THEN
dialogues.text: Curtain down, house lights on.. and over the speaker system the famous ditty ‘I'M JUST A GIRL WHO CAN'T SAY NO’ - sung by ‘Ado Annie’, Gloria’s character in ‘OKLAHOMA’. The gimmick that sends the audience merrily on their way.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. DUKE’S PLAYHOUSE THEATRE/STAGE - CONTINUOUS Gloria shimmying her shoulders as STAGEHANDS pack up.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (softly singing) “I'm just a fool when lights are low, I can't be prissy and quaint-- I ain't the type what can faint-- How can I be what I ain't? I can’t say no”.  INT. DUKE’S PLAYHOUSE THEATRE/DRESSING ROOM - NIGHT Gloria de-robing. The high wearing off, the beginning of a comedown she knows all too well. In the flesh she looks THIN. The wrong type of thin. SUDDENLY Gloria clutches her stomach; face contorted. WIDEN OUT as she collapses to the floor. EXT. ALLEYWAY/BELLA AND JOE’S HOUSE - NIGHT PETER TURNER, 28, a strapping Scouser, walking home from ‘work’ down a rough Liverpool back alley. Note he has faint traces of THEATRE MAKE-UP that he’s not cleaned off properly... The alley leads onto a street full of red-bricked Victorian Terrace Houses. He stops outside NUMBER 8 the house where he grew up, strange he’s back, ‘nice strange’. Brother Joe’s FORD CAPRI parked on the path. He wanders in.. INT. BELLA AND JOE’S HOUSE/KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS BELLA (70), Peter’s mum, cooks sausages for older brother JOE (40), his curvaceous wife JESSIE (38) sits playfully in his lap. JOE SNR (71), a man of greying countenance, is trailed by CANDY the mongrel dog as he scours the kitchen for the dog’s lead.

dialogues.speaker: JESSIE
dialogues.text: Y’might be staying in a luxury hotel Bella. Y’know three star and that, maybe more..

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be staying in a bloody luxury hotel!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And be waited on hand and foot? Like the ‘Queen of Sheba’?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Joseph, my ‘Queen of Sheba’ days disappeared down the swanny the day I married your bloody father. 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scowls at Joe Snr, now even more desperate to escape. Suddenly Peter bowls in nearly knocking him over. They just give each other a canny look.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Seen the dog’s lead?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not my department.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Desperate here lad.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: (at Joe Snr) Sixteen years I’ve waited for this trip! You knew all about this stopover didn’t you? Y’big lump of lard! Forgot to tell me ‘till now. We’re supposed to be off next Tuesday. I would never have agreed if I’d known.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Sod this. Joe Snr disappears with the dog sans lead. Bella watches him bang the door on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (notices) Y’mean apart from you wearing bloody eye-liner. Jesus wept. Joe seriously can’t believe it. Peter rushes to the sink and rubs it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody actors, dressing up as birds, putting make-up on. Weird way to make a living for a bloke if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No-one’s asking you ‘soft lad’. And I’m not playing a bird.. I’m playing ‘a nurse’ ina Allan Bleasdale play.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Can’t wait for this bloody ‘play’ thing to end so you can bugger off back to London. Where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Joseph! Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe doesn’t mess with Bella. The lads flick ‘Vs’ like kids do, behind Bella’s back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Bella) You look stressed, ma. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Course she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ma..?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Well.. I’ve just been reliably informed, by looking at the bloody tickets, that there’s a twenty four hour stopover in Manila when we fly back from Australia.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Manila, eh? Nice.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: No Peter. Not nice. Not nice at all. (collects herself) I‘1ll have just said goodbye to your brother Billy... maybe the last time ever--

dialogues.speaker: PETER JOE
dialogues.text: Don’t be daft.. Don’t say that!

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No you two don’t be daft! I won't be going back all that way again, and our Billy won’t be coming back to Liverpool, ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA (CONT’D) So, yes, it’s probably the last time I’1l1 see him before I leave this world. The last time, understand? pause) And I’1l be thinking about that, I know I will. And I don’t want be thinking about that on bloody 24 hour stopover in Manila! I don’t even know where the bloody place is!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh Ma come on. It’1l be fine. It’s just your first time on an airplane and that.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s what I said!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s a big deal. And not having seen our Billy for so long.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Sixteen bloody years...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You're bound to be a bit, y'know... edgy. The PHONE in the hallway rings out. Joe pats Jessie’s arse signalling for her to get up so he can answer.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mere. Peter goes gives his Mum a soothing hug.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: God, I’ve missed him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know Ma. We all have. (pause) The selfish git. Bella playfully hits him.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: You’re all bloody heartbreakers I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA_, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They don’t tell you that when your legs are laced-up in stirrups. Giving birth’s the easy bit. Joe comes back in - perturbed look.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Some director bloke, asking if you know Gloria Grahame. EVERYONE’S ears prick up on hearing THAT NAME.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Says she’s not well.. A WORRIED Peter jumps up; follows him to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Pete Turner speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford Capri firing its way towards Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that’s all he said? INT. FORD CAPRI —- CONTINUOUS 10 A bewildered Peter in the back seat - Joe drives, Jessie sits next to him. All are visibly worried.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s all he’d say on the phone, ‘extremely serious’. (frustrated) What the hell does that even mean? Why can’t directors just say how it is? (pause) She’s got form for stunts like this Gloria..

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How'd y’mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She’s not scared to ‘cry wolf’. *  10 11 12

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well. Let’s hope she is then, eh? The car carries on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gloria? Peter lets himself in, squints through the darkness. Gloria in bed... in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (terse) Gloria?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, remember me then?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Peter. I’ve missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (a flash of frustration) Course. That’s why you didn’t tell me you were in England?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t be angry

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah well, it’s a bit of a shock to get a call saying you're sixty miles up the M6.. And now you’re ill I hear...? (pause) What’s going on Gloria?.. I can’t see properly. Peter moves towards her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t come so close honey. Sit on the other bed. Peter sits down, next to him an open SUITCASE with a few basic clothes; a bunch of PUBLICITY POSTCARDS of Gloria from her film ‘The Bad And the Beautiful’.. Peter’s seen this post-card before. He notes the sheet purposely covering her face.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s gas. I got gas in my stomach that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Let me see your face. Peter takes the risk, slowly pulls the sheet down. Gloria’s face - a waxy grey pallor, crusted make-up. Hair knotted to the roots. ON PETER’S ALARM Suddenly Gloria convulses in a fit of coughs. Peter helps her upright; puts a glass of water to her lips; she manages to take a few sips. The coughing fades..

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you seen a Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No! No doctors. They got me like this in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This sounds bad, you need to see someone?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I wanna see your Mom. Take me to your home, Peter. Bella, she’1ll look after me. I can get better there. (beat) Take me to Liverpool... Peter more confused than ever--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You sure that’s a good idea? I mean you and me..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee FH HF

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It’s the only idea I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light breaking of Liverpool. The Ford Capri drives past an art deco sky-scraper which wouldn’t look out of place on 5th Avenue. Gloria in Peter’s arms covered by a heavy blanket - looking out.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Liverpooool... INT. BELLA AND JOE’S HOUSE/KITCHEN - DAWN 14 Bella and Joe Snr waiting, when Joe comes in with Jessie. They try to warn them with their looks.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Well?? How is the girl? Before he can reply Peter and Gloria appear. Bella’s eyes widen, Joe Snr slowly puts the paper down.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Hey Bella.. Hey Pops...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Gloria luv.. how are you?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I’m OK.. Or will be.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I said she could stay with us Ma. ‘Till she gets better.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Of course she can.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It won't be for long Bella, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Stay as long as you want my luv. We've really missed you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ma, she needs to go to bed straight away.  14 15 11.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Of course. Peter and Gloria head out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could have warned me. I’d have put the electric blanket on. Joe, Bella and Joe Snr left on the kitchen exchanging strange looks. They turn to Joe for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (grabs the suitcase) I best, er, take this up. He heads out to the stairs Jessie follows. Bella looks at Joe Snr... she also heads for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room stuck in the 50's; antique wardrobe; dressing table with wrap around mirror; wrought iron bed by a sash window. POPE JOHN PAUL II on the wall. Peter helps Gloria sit on the bed. Joe places the suitcase on an and old rocking chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Downstairs if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thanks Joe.. Joe and Jessie look at Gloria then leave.. passing Bella on her way in.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: It’s like a bloody igloo in here. She turns the radiator tap on.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you hungry luv? Can I get you anything? Gloria erupts coughing. Peter has to hold her tight. Bella taking in Gloria - her complexion, her frailty.  15 12.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s fine Ma. I’ll be down ina bit. Bella takes the hint, leaves. Gloria reaches into her green wash-bag (which she finds in her separate VANITY CASE), finds her BROKEN MIRROR; finds her reflection. Reflection shot: GINNY TREMAINE in ‘CROSSFIRE’. She puts the mirror down. They glance at each other awkwardly, air hanging heavy like a dulling wine. Peter opens her suitcase; finds her CREAM SILK PYJAMAS. Then his eyes drift over a MEDICAL DISCHARGE SHEET from Lancaster General Hospital. Finally he spots the GOLD HEART-SHAPED PENDANT, he picks it out. Studies it with intimate surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..-you kept it. They linger in regretful eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Of course I did.. It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I never got to give it to you properly..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (solemn) Peter... the way we left it in New York--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) --Glo. You need to rest... And I need to call your family in

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: --No! Peter looks taken back.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’1l1 only worry, and gossip.. and anyway I’m gonna be fine! Seriously! So don’t bother anyone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Y’sure?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. She’s adamant, Peter shrugs.. Her call. Then his attention drawn to her BLACK SUEDE STILETTOS.. he unpacks them from the case.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I bought these with you on Bond Street, remember?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: They’re my ‘Ruby Red Slippers’. (pause) Primrose Hill. We had fun right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Lots of it. Suddenly Gloria’s breathing seizes up; she gulps and swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Burp me Peter.. please... Peter rubs her back ‘till she gradually gets her breath back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’1l get you some water.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Milk please baby, y’know I love milk. Peter nods, rises. FOLLOW him out, and in ONE SHOT--

dialogues.speaker: TRANSITION TO
dialogues.text: INT. PRIMROSE-HILL HALLWAY/GLORIA’S ROOM - DAY 16 Peter walking down a tatty hallway, paint peeling, discarded mail on the floor. CAPTION: PRIMROSE HILL, LONDON - 1979.  16 14.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Loo Poo Boo Moo Lah Pah Bah Mah’. Intrigued by ‘actor-ish’ noises he creeps to the door from which it emanates.. reveal it’s slightly ajar. PETER’S POV: Gloria, 56 but stealing late 30's; subtly glamorous in 501’s, cropped T-shirt, peering in a full length mirror doing vocal/facial warm-ups.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: “No, said he. Away, said she. ‘A’ sitting very prettily by a chestnut tree." Peter smiles.. somewhat smitten.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Fluffy floppy puppy--

dialogues.speaker: DIDI, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: My new tenant’s arrived. Peter spins round guiltily to see DIDI THE LANDLADY down the corridor relishing her third gin of the day.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C)
dialogues.text: ‘Sally Saw Silvestre Stacking Saucers Side by Side.’ Peter and Didi listen and titter.

dialogues.speaker: DIDI
dialogues.text: Like ‘My Fair bleeding Lady’.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know what she’s doing.. vocal exercises. Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: DIDI
dialogues.text: She’s an actress. Famous one too... Or was.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s she called?

dialogues.speaker: DIDI
dialogues.text: ‘Gloria Grahame’. Always played the tart.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doesn't ring a bell.  16 17 15.

dialogues.speaker: DIDI
dialogues.text: Big name in black and white films. Not doing too well in colour though.. obviously.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: DIDI
dialogues.text: Well, she ‘aint swanning about Sunset Boulevard now is she Peter luv? No, she’s renting a room in my house talking bloody nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Paul pruned Penelope's pansies leaving poor Penelope perplexed’. Peter, intrigued by Didi’s insight...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Dunno Didi. She sounds pretty colourful to me. They smile as he heads back to his NEXT DOOR ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter checking his mail box, spots Gloria stood at her door watching him, smoking, dark glasses. Sultry.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Next door guy, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (nods ) Which makes you ‘the girl next door’. They check each other out - a buzz between them.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Hey, you seen the movie ‘Saturday Night Fever’?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Three times. 16 17  17 18 19 16.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You like disco dancing?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I like drunk dancing.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So if I fix you a drink will you come in my room and hustle with me? I need a partner for my dance class.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fix me a drink and I'll clean your bathroom too. Gloria laughs, disappears inside. Peter shrugs - what the hell - follows her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establisher of the house. ‘More Than A Woman’ by the Bee Gees from ‘SNF’ drifts over the street. INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS - CONTINUOUS Gloria leads Peter in complicated dance moves. Peter not quite in step, getting a sweat-on. Gloria coyly stripped to her strap top. She barks out moves to which Peter sweetly obeys.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: We got some moves goin’ on here!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They miscast Travolta. (Tony Manero/Travolta) “Would ya just watch the hair!"

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It’s him!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I got a better bum... The music/dancing stops. She looks him up and down. 17 18 19  19 17.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I noticed. (pause) You’re an actor too right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I pretend to be.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What you working on?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Tables, chairs, sideboards..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I work in a second hand furniture shop right now. In between acting jobs I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid, honey. We’ve all been there. There’s heat between them. And they know it.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me fix you another drink? I got some nice bourbon.. Peter checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I promised a friend I’d go to the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: A ‘Him’ or a ‘Her’ friend.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A ‘Him’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (small smile) What you going to see?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘Krapps Last Tape’ by Samuel Becket.  18.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I hope it’s better then it sounds.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s a one man play.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I love those things.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You get to say all the lines. They both smile. Gloria fixes herself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well.. pop in anytime. We can talk about ‘the craft’? Swap notes and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And more disco?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You bet! Hold on their obvious attraction.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Really nice to meet you Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: And you Peter.. Peter leaves. As soon as the door shuts Gloria CLUCKS THE ROOF OF HER MOUTH. 20 INT. PUB THEATRE —- LATER 20 PATRONS OF THE ARTS watch THE ONE MAN performing. Peter at the back with DAN (late 20’s) - trendy Bryan Ferry haircut. They talk in whispers..

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You're sure it’s actually her?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, she’s called Gloria. She’s American.. she looks film actress-y..  19.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: and she says she splits her time between a place in LA and her Manhattan apartment... All sounds pretty ‘Hollywood’ to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Don’t believe it... all a ruse. *

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: To lure young naive, northern men into a deviant web of mental manipulation and sexual depravity.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (pause) Sounds good. DAN sneaks an arm round Peter’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (semi-joky) But what about us darling?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (sarcy) * What about ‘us’? * Peter warmly clasps his hand. *

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Us’ are just fine and dandy * Daniel. * Rubs it affectionately. But in his eyes we see a tiny * seed of doubt. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice and wide as Peter walks into his digs..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters, puts his key in his door WHEN HE HEARS--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (screech)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter rushes to Gloria’s door. BANGS ON. Nothing. He turns the handle, it opens slightly - then gets rammed shut from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Oh no you don’t!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s Peter! Are you ok?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is it serious?!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Shall I call 999?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (pause) Do they have spare shirts?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Y’what?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (pause) I’m dying my eyelashes and I’ve spilt the goddamn stuff all over my shirt. Gloria opens the door slightly, we can tell she’s shirtless (bra on) - her eyes meet Peter’s.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Peter you couldn’t help me out, My other shirt is in the laundry..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You only have two shirts?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How many do you have?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: More than two.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So I can borrow one right?  22 23 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JUMP CUT TO - Peter approaching Gloria’s door fresh shirt in hand when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘La Poo Boo Moo..' He leaves his shirt on her door handle. INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS - NIGHT 23 Gloria left her door ajar accidently on purpose. Peter wanders up clutching a bottle of wine and a HAND-WRITTEN NOTE - stops to enjoy his voyeur opportunity. POV: Gloria dressed in Peter’s shirt, rehearsing lines, (Clemence Dane’s adaptation of ‘Rain’). She paces around, throwing looks into the full length mirror getting into character as Sadie Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE/GLORIA
dialogues.text: “How do you know what I've suffered! Your God and my God could never be shipmates"”. Gloria stands staring at herself, passionate as Sadie. Then breaks out, paces around, mutters lines to herself - different variations.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE/GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (variation) “How do you know what I've suffered?" Steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE/GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softer) “You tell him Sadie Thompson is on her way to hell.” She plays with her range/her emotions. Then drops all pretence - steps right up to the mirror so her nose is touching... looks through herself. Peter finally knocks on. She raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (Shakespearean) “Hark, how they knock..” As if she knew Peter was there all along. She walks over and gently pulls the door open all the way.  23 24 22.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (coquettish) Peter..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hope I’m not disturbing.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Hell no. I love it when strange men come knocking on my door with bottles booze.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Er.. I got your note. It was on my bed. He shows her the NOTE.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading it) “Hey Peter, don’t forget to call in---”

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Sshh.. Don’t ruin it for me. She stands aside to let him in. Peter passes the wine. The door shuts us out. INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS —- MOMENTS LATER Gloria hands a glass of wine to Peter, she carries on with a GLASS OF MILK.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Liverpoooool. I just wanna go to Liverpoooool. That’s how you pronounce it right? Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Liverpool.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Liverpooool.. Love it. ‘The Fab Four’, right?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You remind me of Lennon. 23 24

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you got the nose and the attitude.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ahu.. I see him sometimes walking in Central Park with that crazy beautiful chic of his, they look so cool. They look goood on each other know what I mean? Some couples just look right. They eye each other up CLOSELY; both know she’s meaning THEY would look good together too.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gotta take me there someday, Liverpooool. Peter giggling like a kid.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (playful) Peter you’re laughing at me you meanie. Peter sits on the sofa - fidgety. He notices a copy of ‘Being and Nothingness’ by Jean Paul Sartre on the arm of the sofa - he flicks through.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “Better to die on one's feet than to live on one's knees”. Gloria looks up - impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Try telling Hollywood that. Gloria hands him his glass - sits at the other end of the sofa so she can get a good look at him. Peter notices she’s sill wearing his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It suits you..  24.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I love wearing men’s clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And I look great in women’s... On Tuesdays Peter becomes ‘Petra’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Well if Petra wants to borrow from my closet just let me know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'll pass it on. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Cheers. They drink... Gloria lets the air sit. Peter picks up her stage-play lying on the coffee table - checks the front cover out. POV: ‘RAIN’.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (flicking through) What’s it about?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (eyes him) Sex.. Sin... Salvation.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sounds heavy...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Just another day at the Gloria Grahame office honey. Peter can’t suppress a giggle.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s so funny? Peter keeps giggling.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I love the way you say stuff!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Touché Sexual jousting.  24 25 26 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Gloria’s GLASS OF MILK as she rests it on a nearby side table--

dialogues.speaker: TRANSITION TO
dialogues.text: INT. BELLA’S GUEST ROOM - NIGHT THE GLASS OF MILK Peter has brought for Gloria (end of sc. 18). He rests it on the bedside table. Gloria laid back, eyes closes. He thinks she’s asleep, when she pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Thanks honey..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You need anything else?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: My mirror honey, my Bogie compact... Peter picks up the compact from the bedside table. Passes it to Gloria, flips it open and on her reflection we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reflection of GLORIA’S LIPS in the compact--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Is my lipstick on right? I was in a rush. Reveal they are in line to see the movie ‘ALIEN’.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Perfectly right. (pause) How’s mine? She laughs squeezes his hand in hers. CINEMA GO-ERS cast furtive glances - recognising her or deliberating whether it’s her or not.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So is this like a date? 24 25

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I thought you could do with a break from rehearsals.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You're so kind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Plus you were sending me mad with all the ‘pooh bah mah’ shite.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Honesty. I like that in a fellah.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (noticing the glances) People are looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How do you know it’s not you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m guessing you’re more interesting to look at than me. Gloria notices the attention now.. INT. CINEMA —- LATER ON THE BIG SCREEN: John Hurt complains about the menu when his stomach starts rumbling.... CUT TO - the AUDIENCE, eyes growing wider. Peter slinking further down in his seat, GLORIA casually popping popcorn. John Hurt’s stomach bursts open! Peter buries his eyes in Gloria’s arm - who is more in awe at the special effects (so different to her day).

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Jeez. Look at those guts everywhere.. ‘aint that something... She sweetly strokes Peter’s head.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You okay down there sweetie? 26 27  27. 28 INT. PUB - LATER —- NIGHT 28 Gloria and Peter burst in with that ‘just-seen-a- great-movie’ energy. Head to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It’s when the small aliens pop out from between your legs that things get complicated... The BARMAN comes over - peering at Gloria. Peter orders two pints.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How many times has that happened to you then?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Oh just the four..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Four!? Gloria not sure how to take this. Peter genuinely flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What? You didn’t think I’d have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn’t expect you to have four, that’s like--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: -One more than three.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I keep ‘em safe.. with my four ex-husbands. Peter has to catch his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I need to powder my nose. Gloria heads off unsure how she’s come out of that; BARMAN arrives with the pints of ale.  28.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Two fifty mate. Peter breaks out of his spell, pays up.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t mean to pry, but is that Gloria ‘whatsername’... Grahame.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m not 100 percent. She says she is.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: I recognise that pout! She was in loads of things in the 50's, a proper film star she was.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Apparently so, yeah..

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Won an Oscar too if my memory serves me right.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Y’what?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, that film she did with Kirk Douglas, forget the name.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: An Oscar? You sure? This hits Peter just as hard as ‘the kids’ reveal.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: She not mentioned it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (reflective) No...

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: If I’d won an Oscar I'd be wearing it round my neck so every Tom Dick and Harry’d would get the message. Knowhat- I-mean son?  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sat opposite. Peter eyeing Gloria with intrigue. The Oscar revelation knocked him off balance. Gloria catches him....

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What, what?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You that’s what... Peter innocently points at himself.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, you mister. You’ve gone all quiet on me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m just ‘The strong, silent type’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Think Robert Redford y’know.. ‘The Sundance Kid’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: OK I’m thinking... and I like that thought. They hold each others eyes... enjoying the sights.

dialogues.speaker: FLICK IN
dialogues.text: 30 INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS - LATER - NIGHT 30 Gloria hands a large glass of bourbon to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Cheers. They clink glasses and drink.  30 30.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This is becoming a habit.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I like habits. Especially bad ones. She clucks her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, I gotta question. How do you join the Royal Shakespeare Company?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don’t just fill a form out. I think you get invited to apply.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How do you get invited?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Through your agent. Or they head-hunt you I imagine. I mean I don’t know for sure, I wish I did.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: OK, I’1l let my agent know...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: ‘Coz I really wanna play Juliet for the ‘RSC’.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Juliet??

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (laughs ) You mean the Nurse don’t you?! Gloria... a slow rage begins to engulf her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I get it. You think I’m too old to play Juliet huh?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter straightens - doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in his face) Huh??? Gloria’s eyes blaze through him.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine! She slams her drink down, marches to the coat stand.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine! Puts on her rain-coat.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I’m just an old lady don’tcha? Too old for you is that what you’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Er.. That’s not what I said. Gloria - too wrapped up in her rage.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well you’re wrong Mister! I’m gonna go to that theatre right now and see one of their shows. Take a look at the competition. Thanks. Thanks a bunch! At least I have a chance to join the ‘RS’ goddamn ‘C’ coz at least I’m an actor who works! Peter jumps in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on, don’t be like this..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Move.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure the RSC even has a performance tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: ‘The Merchant of Venice’. Aldwych Theatre. 7.30. I’ve done my homework!  32.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well I don’t want you to go!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Because-— And with no words left in his locker Peter just grabs hold of Gloria and plants his lips on her. AN intense and long kiss - finally they come up for air.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There! That’s why! A moment where Gloria feels the dizzy after effects. Then BAM! Peter grabs her - lips meet - the pent up frustrations. They smother each other. Clothes hit the floor - Peter hoists her up, Gloria’s legs straddle him, and he marches her into the bedroom. (TRANSITION STEADI-CAM SHOT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STILL ROTATING... come round on Peter - now find him sat, gazing with DEEP CONCERN at a SLEEPING GLORIA... the camera keeps going... moves behind Peter, AND WE...

dialogues.speaker: MIX TO
dialogues.text: 32 INT. WATFORD THEATRE — NIGHT 32 Come off PETER’s BACK to discover HIM consuming a VIBRANT Gloria play Sadie Thompson on OPENING NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE/GLORIA
dialogues.text: "You tell him Sadie Thompson is on her way to hell!!"

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A PACKED THEATRE glued to Gloria's performance.  33 34 33. INT. WATFORD THEATRE — CONTINUOUS 33 THE HUGE APPLAUSE continues as Gloria takes her curtain call. She plays it like the Hollywood pro she is. Peter is on his feet, wolf whistling. Gloria throws him a personal cross-eyed wink which he loves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzzy 1st night party. Gloria and Peter in the midst quaffing champagne, LOTS OF ADMIRERS and people wanting to shake her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.. Thanks. Thank you so much... The producer GEORGE bustles over, takes her in his arms. They luvvie kiss. Peter notes he squeezes Gloria’s waist tighter than is appropriate..

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Superlatives are redundant darling.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Oh Georgie, you got me going all red. Gloria adept to a director’s praise. Enjoys it.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Georgie... this is my good friend Peter. (to Peter) Georgie produced this gig. George gives Peter the once over, doesn't shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah Hi. (back to Gloria) There’s an exquisite brasserie in Soho. We could stay up, wait for the rave reviews?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Oh I'd love to..  34.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Peter can come too right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Er.. Just then a PR PERSON intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: PR PERSON
dialogues.text: Gloria we're ready for the photocall out front.. Gloria heads off with Peter.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Gimmee a minute. They leave George stranded, Peter gives him a cheeky wink as he passes; they meander through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (in Gloria's ear) George wants to fuck you..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Darling, everyone here wants to fuck me! They laugh like lovers do.

dialogues.speaker: 35-36 OMITTED 35-36
dialogues.text: 36A INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS/BEDROOM - LATER - NIGHT Peter and Gloria GETTING IT ON.. SUDDENLY Peter, stops, looks Gloria deep in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I got a question.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Shoot. It’s a funny time to ask one and they both know it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So apparently you're 'the girl who can't say no' right?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Apparently yeah..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But am I right in thinking the girl who can’t say no is now saying a big ‘yes’ to Peter Turner? They smile like naughty teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: YESyesyesyesyesyesyeyesYES! CUT TO - MASSIVE PRIMROSE HILL WIDE as they maul each other with lust. INT. PRIMROSE HILL/GLORIA’S BEDROOM - MORNING Peter’s eyes meet the morning shards of light. Excited to be alive as he has his arms wrapped around Gloria, still seemingly asleep.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (whispers) Are you awake?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (pause) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I can tell. Peter kisses her neck - then tickles her around the ribs, flipping her over so that she’s underneath him. They lock eyes, then he starts brushing his lips on her ear and her neck, dropping his head towards her chest.. Then to her RIGHT BREAST.. Peter’s POV: A SMALL SCAR. He gently runs his finger across it. Gloria softly takes his hand; sends it south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinds drawn, 16mm Projector plays ‘HUMAN DESIRE’. A train steams through America’s Midwest... +e 37 38  38 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘COLUMBIA PICTURES PRESENT GLENN FORD and.. GLORIA GRAHAME in.. HUMAN DESIRE.’ Gloria sat with HEAD LECTURER (BRIAN) - Peter sits amongst the banks of STUDENTS packed into the room. ANGLE ON SCREEN: VICKI (Gloria) sits by the train tracks, pouring her heart out to JEFF (Glenn Ford).

dialogues.speaker: VICKI/GLORIA
dialogues.text: “After I married I felt a little unhappy, but I figured that wasn't so important. Most women are unhappy... They just pretend they are”. JUMP TO: The climax. VICKI laying into her down and out husband CARL in a moving train carriage.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI/GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “I wanted him to get rid of that wife of his! But he wasn't quite the fool you are! And you know what? I admired him for it! If I'd have been a man I would behave exactly like he did. Now get out and let me unpack!" But Carl doesn’t ‘get out’ or ‘let her unpack’ - instead he throttles her to death. GLORIA takes a quick peek at herself in her COMPACT. Reflection shot: VICKI BUCKLEY

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: ‘RKO PICTURES PRESENT ‘THE NAKED ALIBI’... ‘STARRING STERLING HAYDEN AND GLORIA GRAHAME...’ JUMP TO: Gloria playing ‘MARIANNA’ the hooker in ‘El Purico Cantina’. The piano plays; she spins on her stool to face the liquored-up testosterone lined up around her. SHE SINGS ‘ACE IN THE HOLE’... and it’s ‘mucho’ sexy. On Peter glued to the screen; bowled over by this amazing performance; the heat she gives; that she’s his girlfriend  38 37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The credits for ‘The Naked Alibi’ roll to A BIG CLAP. Gloria stands, gives a small curtsy, looks over at Peter for affirmation he rolls his eyes in admiration. BRIAN stands up to address his flock. More big

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: ‘They don’t make ‘em like that anymore’. So guys, it’s not often a bona fide Hollywood legend pops in for a chat.. She’s starred in 36 feature films, bagging an Oscar on the way. She’s certainly one of my favourite actress’. Please give her a warm London Film School welcome... Gloria Grahame everyone. applause. Gloria smiles and stays seated.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I’m shocked you guys have even heard of me! Seriously!

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: We’re gonna do this freestyle, so fire away. BRIAN points to a FRESH FACED STUDENT. Chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: FRESH FACED STUDENT
dialogues.text: What was it like playing Ado Annie in Oklahoma and do you think it’s your most famous role?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well I warned them about giving me ‘Annie’, basically I can’t sing. But the director told me he was just after the ‘twinkle in my eye’.... I guess that’s all he got, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it my most famous role? Well, I suppose I’1ll always be the ‘Girl who can’t say no’. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I totally rock at saying ‘yes’. It’s a killer line. She winks at Peter and clucks the roof of her mouth. Brian points to another hand - SERIOUS STUDENT. Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SERIOUS STUDENT
dialogues.text: Hi Gloria. Is acting a great job or a vocation to you?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well.. my mother was an acting coach so I was thrust on stage at 6 years old. I love theatre.. but somehow I ended up in movies ..and that was fun... but I just can’t stomach the movie-star-dick-swinging bull shit. It sent me nuts. Now Lana Turner! Boy, she could swing for the Olympics. But my acting? It became my art and a vocation... definitely.

dialogues.speaker: INTRIGUED STUDENT
dialogues.text: Was the famous ‘Hollywood system’ tough to deal with?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (thinks ) I was known as ‘The Replacement’ in the studios. Never first choice, and the ‘suits’ know that, they can use it... Seems only yesterday I was hanging round the MGM lot snapping garters for the price of cup of a coffee. Time passes by so quickly. I’m real jealous of all you guys setting out. A YOUNG HIPPY TYPE type stands up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hey Gloria, I’m Eddie it’s cool you're here. Like really cool.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Thanks Eddie.. it’s cool to be here. + ee HH *

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Er. You’ve worked with so many cool directors. Like really cool guys, Fritz Lang, Dmytryk, Minelli. De Mille.. Er, so I just wanna know. Like what makes a good director and what makes a bad one? Gloria looks flummoxed.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well I guess a good director’s good.. and a bad director's bad. The places erupts with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Cool Gloria... Brian picks another hand..

dialogues.speaker: GOSSIPY STUDENT
dialogues.text: You also worked with your second husband Nick Ray as a director?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I did...

dialogues.speaker: GOSSIPY STUDENT
dialogues.text: Whilst going through a messy divorce too, what was that like?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Messy. Next. 39. 38 Another student pipes up. Female, political looking.

dialogues.speaker: POLITICAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: Do you think your generation of ‘silver screen starlets’ let down the next generation of acting women?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: POLITICAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: By being typecast as sex symbols.

dialogues.speaker: POLITICAL STUDENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not fighting for equal rights or pay. We all know ‘leading men’ are offered prime roles well into middle age whilst the women in Hollywood are thrown on the scrap-heap by the time they hit twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Er.. What was the question?

dialogues.speaker: POLITICAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: When did you personally last work on a major Hollywood studio picture, Gloria?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Got a calculator Missy?

dialogues.speaker: POLITICAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: Yeah..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Then you work it out! The student has hit her Achilles. Which was the plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38A INT. LONDON FILM SCHOOL - MOMENTS LATER —- DAY Applause as the Q&A ends. Gloria - slightly awkward. The clapping dies, student pack up, Peter walks to the front. Gloria can’t wait to subtly grab him for security...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Amazing!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I hate people talking about my career. I hate talking about my career.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What? Everyone loved you.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah! And what was that in ‘The Naked Alibi’?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘Marianna’. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You liked her?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, I liked her all right..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I keep forgetting you ‘aint seen these things before..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You play one great hooker. A natural. She hits him playfully.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gloria, you need to give yourself a bigger pat on the back for all this great acting. I mean your career is gob- smacking. . Gloria looks at him like he’s mad. But she knows he REALLY MEANS IT, and that really means A LOT to her.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 39
dialogues.text: EXT. BOND STREET SHOE SHOP - MOMENTS LATER -— DAY 40 Establisher of the historical ‘CHURCH'S’ SHOE SHOP. Peter and Gloria happen to be walking by, Gloria clocks the ‘snazzy chaussures’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So you think I need to give myself a bigger pat on the back huh?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: In my opinion yeah..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Let’s back that opinion up then.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gloria takes Peter’s hand; leads him into the store.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (OVER-LAP)
dialogues.text: Peter! I am going crazy here! INT. BOND STREET SHOE SHOP - CONTINUOUS - DAY 4l Gloria surrounded by shoes, all discarded. Peter like a spare part. Gloria WEARS HER BLACK SOCKS - strange for woman trying on shoes (apparently).

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Why do none of them fit? Don’t answer that. It’s my fat feet.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re not fat.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I never said I’m fat. I know I’m not fat, but my feet need to go on a diet. A SNOTTY SHOP ASSISTANT returns with a shoe-box.

dialogues.speaker: SNOTTY ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: These are the last pair we have Madam. She unveils the BLACK SUEDE STILETTOS. Gloria’s eyes light up. JUMP TO - Gloria forcing her feet into the shoes. First the right then the left..

dialogues.speaker: SNOTTY ASSISTANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sighs) It would probably help if one did not wear socks whilst trying on the shoes. Both for Madam’s fit, and for the sake of the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: posh English) Oh, does one indeed? Well Madam doesn’t agree. Hollywood accent) I always wear socks. It’s my constitutional right to wear my socks. calmer) Plus they hide my fat feet!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The whole shop AWARE. Gloria forces her right foot into the shoe, stands up, looks in the mirror - does a little yelp of joy. Turns to the ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nice as pie) I’1l take these please honey. INT. GLORIA’S PRIMROSE ROOMS/BEDROOM - DAY Come off a pile of clothes including the NEW BLACK SUEDE SHOES to find Peter and Gloria in bed; post- orgasm.. mutual, judging by the flushed faces. Peter un-glues himself as Gloria reaches for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I thought this stuff only happened in the movies.. They stare at the ceiling and burst out laughing. THEN... THE BED BEGINS TO ROTATE, like the most natural thing in world -- AND WE --

dialogues.speaker: TRANSITION TO
dialogues.text: INT. BELLA’S GUEST ROOM —- PRESENT DAY Early evening, next day. Peter still in bed with Gloria in his arms, still sleeping. Not the vibrant person from Primrose Hill. He gently unhooks himself. INT. BELLA AND JOE’S KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER - DAY BELLA sorting a HOT WATER BOTTLE for Gloria. Joe Senior subconsciously ANNOYS HER, tinkering with a BROKEN TV. Peter enters, slumps at the kitchen table. His parents both look at him expectantly for news.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She’s still sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Well, you got here very late.. or early. The bloody birds were singing. You could have rang ahead. Gave me some warning. 41 42 43 44

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sorry Ma. It was a struggle to get her out of the hotel never mind into the car.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: She looks in a bad way.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s ‘gas’ in her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: (confused) ‘Gas’?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s what Americans call indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Well.. I don’t know anything... But I hope it’s that luv. BELLA kisses him on the top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope so.. She heads out of the kitchen. PETER goes to the fridge, tries to swig from a bottle of milk - can’t stomach it; looks back at his Dad and the TV.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: (notices) Dumped in a skip on Lark Lane.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Probably for a reason dad.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Help us into the shed with it and I'll treat you to a pint. Peter motions upstairs and Gloria - he CAN’T.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your Ma’s here if Gloria wakes up.. she’ll sort her out. Peter still unsure..  44 45 46 45.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, have a pint with your ‘arl Fellah’.. spitting feathers ‘ere. Peter nods. Father and son heave the telly off... EXT. ALLEYWAY - MOMENTS LATER —- DAY 45 Peter and Joe Snr walk CANDY on their way for a pint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CANDY lies by Joe Snr’s feet as the men sup bitter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ma’s only just got rid of that rusty fish tank you found.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Well all the gold fish died didn’t they? And she doesn’t like to see anything dead does she?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’1l never get that TV to work Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: You can bring anything back to life son. All you need is a patience and a spark. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saw all her films y’know, me and y’Ma. Big fans of Gloria we were...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I knew you’d seen her films.. didn’t know you were fans.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Well.. we didn’t know what to say when she turned up the first time. A bit embarrassed I suppose... We expected the sort of Gloria Grahame from Birkenhead or Penny Lane.  46

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR_, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not that Gloria Grahame from the Woolton Picture Palace. We never expected that Gloria Grahame in our kitchen necking a bacon butty asking for the ‘tommy’ sauce... it was bit of a shock. (smiles) She was a blokes actress though.. That one with Bogart--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘In a Lonely Place’.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: Ae. Gorgeous mouth. You knew you'd get sore lips if you walked her home. Peter appreciates this - he did walk her home. INT.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What should I do Dad?

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: She needs to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She won’t. She doesn’t like * them.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: No-one likes them when they bring bad news. (pause) We'll care for her of course, but she needs her family if she’s sick. She needs to be with her own...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA AND JOE'S HOUSE/BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: Peter watching over Gloria as she sleeps. Her * breathing irregular, not right, a loud mucus noise as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she inhales. * Silently he leaves the room. *  47 48 49 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter peers upstairs in the direction of spare room THEN reluctantly, moves to the phone, picks it up, tatty address book open in hand, he dials..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Operator. International please. (pause) United States, California... Peter gives a number and it CONNECTS. Then with a sudden CHANGE OF HEART he slowly put the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSITION TO
dialogues.text: INT. ‘LAX’ FOYER - FLASHBACK - DAY 48 PETER’S CLEAN POV TAKES US INTO A SHINY NEW AMERICAN WORLD. . The foyer doors slide open revealing an EXCITED GLAMOUROUS GLORIA arriving to collect her LIVERPOOL MAN. She flings her arms in the air with joy at the sight of her man. Swing back round on Peter, carrying an old suitcase, over-dressed for the heat. They rush into each others arms and share a good old fashioned snog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glistening, sunshiny day. Gloria driving Peter in her VW BEETLE - roof down. Peter stripped to his vest, Ray-Bans on living the Hollywood dream. ‘Good Vibrations’ on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Everything feels so sunshiny! Like the air’s full of--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: -Hollywood horse-shit, I know. Both chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, I wanna show you something.  49 50 48.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gloria brakes and spins the car like a stunt driver so that they end up travelling the opposite way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria and Peter peering through HUGE ENTRANCE GATES at an ART DECO MANSION of epic proportions.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jeez!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: A-hu.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A bit bigger than my Mum and Dad’s house in Liverpool.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I looove your folks pad. It’s my favourite house in the world! Peter smiles with pride - Gloria means it too!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s it like, living ina place like this?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Fun.. for a while. (pointing) Bogey and Betty lived right over there.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Next door??

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ahu..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you see a lot of them?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: We were friendly at first.. but then Cy, my husband, and Bogey had some beef about Bogey’s dogs barking at night. They ended up threatening each other over the fence with shotguns. (pause) I loved Humphrey..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He gave me the best acting * advice once... (Bogey accent) “Just keep it in the shadows * Gloria, let the camera come to you.” (pause) Ain’t that the best? (pause) A few times Bogey would call me up... late... Gloria trails off thinking. She CLUCKS.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that Betty Bacall... (clucks ) * she always looks so damned good. I couldn’t compete with that. Peter glances at Gloria as she stares into her past. *

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (snaps out of it) * Come on... I don’t want my ex- husband catching me peeping into my past.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?? Y’mean he still lives here! ?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Course he does. Why wouldn’t * he? Gloria quickly backs off to the car, Peter follows casting a glance back. Gloria - one big jigsaw he’s constantly trying to piece together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VW BEETLE cruising past Malibu Beach and its luxurious, silly-money beach houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car parked up. Peter and Gloria stare out...  50.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So this is your current LA mansion?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “Awesome”, that how you say it?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: That’s how we say it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s so you...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Come in. I’1l give you the grand tour. They exit the car and we reveal Gloria’s mansion to be a FUNKY TRAILER - pastel shaded, beautifully maintained, perched on a prime cliff top spot overlooking the Malibu ocean. 53 INT. TRAILER — CONTINUOUS 53 Peter stood in the kitchen takes the place in. HE’S ALSO TAKING GLORIA IN - it’s been a long time since they made love and he’s in no mood to wait.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: This is the west wing... She feels his ‘energy’... but coyly continues.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The east over there, north, south, yah, pretty much covers it. The place cluttered with PHOTOS OF HER KIDS, books on meditation and self help, cooking contraptions - the PUBLICITY POSTCARD from ‘The Bad and the Beautiful’ (established) in a picture frame on the window sill. Peter picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the only one I like out of thousands taken. Peter nods, picks up another.  53 54 51.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: a photo of a good looking boy.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tim, my eldest. PETER moves in close, can’t help pawing her a little, getting physical.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don’t miss the mansions?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Who needs a house with twelve bathrooms? Plus I ain’t great with a vacuum cleaner. They smile. Gloria does look relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, it’s all just simple. I can grow my tomatoes, look out at the ocean. They both reflect on the oil painting view.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s another view I wanna show ya... I hope you’1l find it just as desire-able. She takes his hand and leads him to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Now this view.. Peter jumps on the bed - looks back up at her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...is my favourite. Gloria shuts us out and joins him. EXT. GLORIA’S TRAILER - LATER 54 Peter sits at a wooden picnic table drinking wine with Gloria, her rouge cheeked MOTHER (JEAN) and older sister JOY who wears a well-worn hippy look.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Peter, you do know that Gloria’s descended from British Royalty?  52.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Like ‘God Save The Queen’ royalty?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Her father’s line descends from John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster, the famous Shakespearean one- (collects herself) “This royal throne of kings, This sceptered Isle, This earth of majesty, This seat of Mars, This other Eden, demi Paradise.... Peter about to clap when--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “This blessed plot, This earth, This England!" A moment. Has she finished??

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Bravo!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: ‘The Bard’ has always been close to my heart from the first time I played Ophelia. One of many roles I should add.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yup. The Bard’s the nuts Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Gloria should play more Shakespeare in my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Lady Macbeth springs to mind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She'd be a straight fit for Juliet don’t you think? She oozes tragic romance.. He shares a knowing wink with Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did you end up here from bonnie Scotland?  54 53.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Gloria’s father’s idea, he got a job working behind the scenes on the MGM lot.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Then he ran off with another woman.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It’s the ‘Hollywood Way’.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He moved to New Jersey. I never really saw him after that... I loved Dad, he was cookie like me... I miss him.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He was a grade ‘A’ asshole. Peter sees the unresolved issues all round.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You must be very proud of your daughter...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It was obvious she'd be successful. I only wish she’d tried a little harder.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I'm right here by the way Mother. Joy getting jealous.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: She was just as good an actress as the other blonde you know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Y’know.. the nice girl that had an affair with The President. Peter smiles with his eyes. Joy looks over - she’s been glugging the wine.  54.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Peter how old are you? If you don’t mind me asking? Gloria shoots Joy a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: 28 last time I looked.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (to Mom) Oh... not that much younger than Tim then.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Gloria) Tim, your first son right? Gloria nods - doesn’t like where this is heading.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tim’s dad was Nick Ray who directed ‘Rebel Without A Cause’... Hollywood Big Shot.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: James Dean’s a god to me.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It’s a strange set up don’t you think though Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Gloria has other sons she must have mentioned?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, two.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: With her fourth husband.. Tony. (pause) Who also happened to be Gloria’s step-son. IT ALL GOES QUIET. Peter not fully aware before this.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Talk about your own kids okay Joy?  55.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Only filling him in on family history. Nothing to be ashamed about is there?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (to Peter) I'd just divorced Cy. It wasn’t like Tony was a child or anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Not when you got married. (pause) But what about when you first screwed him? Gloria bangs up to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Mother take this bitch home before I take her fucking head off! Gloria stomps off into the trailer leaving a stunned Peter. Finally he gets up..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well I suppose this is goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Do us all a favour Peter... don’t marry Gloria, even if she begs. It would be embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Again. It’s obvious Mother feels the same way as Joy. Peter follows Gloria into the trailer. 55 INT. TRAILER —- CONTINUOUS 55 Gloria angrily washing up. Tries not to clock Peter as he comes in - unsure of his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: That sister of mine can be such a jerk! Gloria starts sniffling.  55 56 56.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m a good mother Peter. You ask any one of my kids and they’11 tell you that. I promise you. Peter taking this in. We aren’t sure how he’ll react.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is what she said true? Gloria finds Peter’s eyes - she looks tired.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Listen Peter, everyone in this town’s already made their mind up. I’m sick of the yapping. Think what you wanna think...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (beat) I think.. It doesn’t matter.. what Joy says or thinks or your Mum.. Or anyone else... Not to me. Peter takes her in his arms. Gloria looks up - needing this.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No? Peter shakes his head smiles, Gloria gradually relaxes, grabs his face and kisses him hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves gently lap the shore. Peter, BARE CHESTED IN LOOSE JOGGING BOTTOMS, cradles Gloria on the bonnet of the VW Beetle looking out at sea.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something... something I’ve never really told anyone before. She faces him.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Only if you want to. 55 56

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I feel the need to be honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: “Honesty’s the best policy.” *

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, I think you should * know... I mean it’s only right * that you know.. * He trails off... struggling.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Go on honey. *

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: In the past, I’ve enjoyed * boyfriends as well as * girlfriends.. so.. yeah.. * Gloria takes it in. Peter hoping he’s not ballsed it.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well... I’ve enjoyed * girlfriends as well as * boyfriends... so I guess that * makes us even. * There’s an even deeper understanding. They kiss. THEN hear a COMMOTION on the beach, a line of silvery-grey splashing on the waters edge.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the ‘Grunion’! Gloria jumps off the car - grabs Peter with her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quick Peter, the ‘Grunion are running’! They only ‘run’ on * special occasions! * Gloria drags him onto the beach; soon they are stood in the most magnificent sight - thousands of GRUNION FISH splashing on the tide-line in a MATING RITUAL.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (unsure) Are they OK?  56 57 58.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Sure they are! They’re making love. They’re in love!!! Just like us Peter! Just like us! Gloria and Peter in love with the grunions. As Gloria rushes out further to be with the fish PETER stays FOREGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSITION TO
dialogues.text: INT. BELLA AND JOE’S HOUSE - MORNING - PRESENT DAY 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks heavily conflicted as he hovers by the phone... He reaches into his pocket; brings out Gloria’s MEDICAL DISCHARGE SHEET (Est Sc. 15). Scan through; nods to his internal dialogue - picks up the phone. Dials. + +e

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello, can I to speak to a- (reads) * Doctor Taylor please? (beat) Yes, Peter Turner I’m a close friend of Gloria Grahame, he treated her a couple of days ago, I’m looking after her at my house-- (pause) I am her boyfriend... * Peter feels good saying ‘her boyfriend’.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor Taylor? (listens) Yes Gloria, that’s right. (listens) Well I’d like to know more about Gloria’s condition, the ‘gas’ in her stomach? (listens) Gas, yes. * (listens) Well, I’m the closest she has to family in England right now. *  57 58

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gloria’s staying with me at my mother and father’s house whilst she gets better...

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Er.. sorry... what? On Peter as TRUTH IS REVEALED.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I mean have you done tests..

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s not said any of this.. She’d have told me. I’m sorry Doctor I need to speak to Gloria, because quite frankly. I don’t believe what I’m hearing. Goodbye. He puts the phone down. WIF!! INT. UPSTAIRS/BELLA’S GUEST ROOM - LATER - DAY Peter intent on understanding. But after a few moments he realises he’s not comprehending.. 59. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handset melting his brain, burning his fingers.. i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ashen Peter (T-shirt on) stops outside the room * when he overhears Bella and Gloria chatting. INTERCUT Bella fixing Gloria’s hair at the dressing table. Gloria looking almost perky.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Did I see Peter coming? Oh my god no, I was forty by then. Thought my child bearing hips had long gone.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You must’ve been just one darned healthy Mamma Bella! So you were shocked right?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Not by then. Nothing shocks me anymore luv. (pause) Except stopovers in bloody Manila.  58 60.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You gotta.. a son always needs his Mom. No matter how old they get. Billy needs you! And if you gotta stay over in Manila to see him then you just gotta do it. Bella ponders Gloria’s wisdom as Peter walks in.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Peter, your Mom’s ironing me out.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: She’s so bloody beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t be daft, those movie idol looks don’t just wither away they’re with you for life.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ohhh.. I love her Peter! Peter confused - at total odds with the joviality.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey baby, do me a big favour, visit the health-food store? I need apricot kernels and black- grape juice.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I suppose so-- Ma?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Health food shop? Round ‘ere? (thinks ) I think there’s one opposite the bookies on Menlove Avenue. 58

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Maybe you should get something for yourself baby, you look wiped. You OK?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m fine. Gloria senses he’s not. Pete backs out of the room, not really in this world. EXT. HEALTH-FOOD SHOP - LATER —- DAY 59 It’s pissing down. Peter approaches the shop, collar up tight but getting soaked; quickly checks the window before disappearing inside. EXT. ALLEYWAY - LATER — DAY 60 Peter carrying Gloria’s health-food needs in a plastic bag trudges home; given up on protecting himself from the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria asleep; A GLASS OF BLACK GRAPE JUICE is laid on the bedside table, then a bowl of apricot kernels. She wakes to a rain-soaked Peter..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Honey.. you’re all wet?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Chucking it down out there. She sits up, takes a tiny sip of grape juice. Finds it difficult to swallow.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gloria.. Y’know I have a performance later, but Mum’s here if you need anything.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (nods ) What’s your director like?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He’s strange...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (thinks ) Truth is I’ve never met a director who made anything better. (pause) Pass me my mirror honey. Peter hands it her, Gloria messes with her hair. Reflection shot: IRENE from ‘SUDDEN FEAR' in pristine black silk pyjamas. Stay on IRENE as Peter talks.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I spoke to the doctor Gloria.. In Lancaster. He’s told me. I know what the ‘gas’ is. Gloria slowly puts the mirror down. Peter holding back his tears..

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Baby... I don’t want any fuss.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t just--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: -I can get better... if you help me I know I can.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What about your family?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: They don't need to know. You, * Bella, Pops, Joe. You’re all I need.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I dunno, maybe a doctor--

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: -No doctors. Just us OK? * Peter knows he’s no choice... nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll get better. I promise. I * know I will... * His head rests into her chest; she softly strokes his hair. Comforting HIM.  62 63 63. INT. BELLA AND JOE’S HOUSE/HALLWAY - LATER - DAY Peter comes down stairs, puts his coat on... off to work.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen) Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah Ma.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In here please. Peter obeys his Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella, Joe, Joe Snr sat at the table, they fix him with worried stares. Peter knows he’s being ambushed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: We all know what’s up luv. With Gloria.. (pause) I’ve seen that look before.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What look?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Your Uncle Tommy had it. Before he passed away. Peter knows she’s referring to the BIG ‘C’.

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: She’s dying.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No she’s not.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What is it then?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s gas. 62 63 + ee

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: It’s not ‘gas’ luv.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don’t take the piss here lad. They stare at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: JOE SNR
dialogues.text: You can start with the truth Peter has a full internal convulsion - it’s an impossible situation, loyalty to Gloria, but can’t hide the truth from his family.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh for fu-- (blurts out) It’s cancer, ok!

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
